Award.AwardTitle: International Symposium: Reconciling Observations and Models of Elastic and Viscoelastic Deformation due to Ice Mass Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI requests funds for travel support for US based scientists, mostly graduate students, postdocs, and junior falculties to attend the International Symposium: Reconciling Observations and Models of Elastic and Viscoelastic Deformation due to Ice Mass Change, to be held in Ilulissat, Greenland (Denmark). This conference will provide an opportunity for US-based scientists to interact with colleagues from around the world to develop Glacial Isostatic Adjustment (GIA) models. Determining the mass balance trend and fluctuations of the Earth's cryosphere in a warming climate is a topic of great interest in the Earth and environmental sciences communities. Present day measurements of changes in the cryosphere do not uniquely constrain the present-day mass balance, because of the long-lasting effects of past mass changes - GIA. GIA is caused by the combined elastic and viscoelastic responses of rock beneath glaciers and ice sheets. Developing these GIA models requires accounting for the mass load history and the physical properties of the earth, integrating glaciology, geodesy and seismology through numerical modeling over a variety of timescales, from the elastic response to the viscoelastic response over decades to centuries to millennia. Results from theses studies are needed for understanding postseismic deformation after earthquakes and reconciling the response of the cryosphere and sea level to climate change.

This proposal will support the participation of US-based scientists, especially early career scientists, in a focused international conference. They will have the opportunity to present their work and interact with global experts in their related fields. They will also gain first hand experience of glaciation during a field trip to Jakobshavn Isbrae, one of the fastest moving glaciers in the world. The topic of the conference is important for a wide range of fields, such as deriving estimates of the present-day response of the cryosphere to climate change, and developing a proper budget for sea level rise and other impacts of a changing climate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported 10 US-based scientists to attend the international conference “Reconciling Observations and Models of Elastic and Viscoelastic Deformation Due to Ice Mass Change”, in Ilulissat, Greenland. This is a topic of intense international interest due to the startling acceleration of mass loss from outlet glaciers and parts of the Greenland ice sheet since the early 2000s. The conference was a small one (about 60 participants), but included most of the leading scientific figures on the topic from around the world. The isolated and immersive setting provided an ideal forum for in-depth discussion and interaction, which was of particular value for the 25 or so early career scientists who benefited from feedback and interaction with each other and with more senior participants. Six of the 10 scientists supported by this award were students, postdocs, or early career faculty. Most of those who received travel support would not have been able to attend the meeting at all without this award, which would have left a significantly reduced US presence at the meeting.

The scope of the meeting was not limited to Greenland, but also encompassed ice mass changes in Antarctica, Alaska, and other regions. While there is a general correlation between warming climate and increasing mass loss, we need to understand the specific causes of the changes. Doing so will require collaboration across several disciplines, and the integration of diverse measurements including ice height change, mass change and gravity change, the physical and mechanical properties of the earth beneath the ice sheets, and the uplift of the solid Earth due to changes in the ice. It will further require a better physical understanding of how glaciers and ice sheets respond to changes in air temperature, ocean temperature, and other factors. Small, focused meetings like this one that bring together experts in many fields to work on the same problem have tremendous value because they encourage scientists to think more broadly, outside of their area of focused expertise, and by encouraging extended discussion and interaction.

Contacts with several of the younger scientists in the roughly two years since the meeting has confirmed that their attendance had a significant impact on their career development. Positive impacts include new knowledge, understanding and ideas, and the development of expanded research contacts.
